abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, given that it was not
            successful in achieving its major objectives of testing and
            demonstrating the feasibility of delivering an essential
            health services package, but did make a contribution to
            policy-making  and planning, as well as capacity building at
            central and district level, and, arguably, paved the way for
            the  coming together of partners in a sector-wide approach,
            the project's achievement is rated as partially
            satisfactory. Despite the problems with the project, and the
            resultant mixed outcomes, the sustainability of the project
            activities - from the programmatic as well as the financial
            perspective - is rated as likely. This assessment is based
            on the fact that the institutions in Uganda, helped by the
            DHSP, are now stronger and the donors  are working
            collaboratively with the government of Uganda and each
            other, within an overall development framework. Given the
            unsatisfactory performance of the Bank at project
            identification, preparation, appraisal and for  part of the
            supervision, and despite the observed improvement in project
            supervision in the latter half of the  project, the
            Bank's overall performance must be rated as
            unsatisfactory. Overall Borrower performance is assessed as
            partially satisfactory. The project was co-funded by the
            Government of Sweden and the Government of the Federal
            Republic of Germany: partner performances were both rated
            satisfactory. Lessons learned included the following: 1) The
            project was implemented at a time when Uganda was just
            recovering  from conflict and internal strife, and
            furthermore had embarked on an ambitious decentralization
            agenda that sought to devolve the responsibility for the
            planning and implementation of essential public  services,
            including health, to district administrations. Such
            devolution of power presents several  unique challenges for
            the design and implementation of Bank supported sectoral
            projects, that need to  be recognized and effectively
            managed, but which were underestimated by the project. 2)
            The project was conceived and designed as a  traditional
            project, but ended up providing broad programmatic support
            and gradually developing a  larger group of development
            partners. The absence of a clear government sectoral policy
            compounded the situation. This raises substantial questions
            about the use of a traditional project as the instrument for
            major sectoral and institutional reform. 3) To be fully
            effective, reform efforts within the health sector need to
            explicitly recognize the politics and political economy of
            the sector; the potential constraints imposed by other
            ongoing reforms; and the need for early and extensive
            consultations with relevant stakeholders in order to ensure
            wide ownership. 4) The project worked with decentralized and
            community-based  organizations, which was a strong
            achievement. However, nongovernmental organizations (NGOs)
            were constrained by having to work  through Local Tender
            Boards. 5) Projects such as this one that work with multiple
            implementing  partners, such as districts, sub-district
            entities, and community-based organizations, faith-based
            organizations, and NGOs need to make multiple advances to
            those implementing partners and thus require correspondingly
            larger Special Accounts. 6) A viable and effective
            monitoring and evaluation framework mutually agreed upon at
            the time of project  preparation is essential. 7) Effective
            donor coordination is vital for the improved performance of
            the health sector.
